column6: Text
On the first day of the three-month retreat, Ajahn Pasanno gives detailed instructions on posture, attending to the breath, arousing energy, and investigating the meaning of mindfulness.
Balancing the body: detailed instructions on sitting posture.
The meaning of Buddho.
Walking meditation instructions.

Reflecting on the third and fourth steps of the Ānāpānasati Sutta (MN 118), Ajahn Pasanno describes entering into the bodily sensations of the breath (kāyasaṅkhārā) as a foundation of training that prepares the mind to receive Dhamma.
[Breath in Mind](), particularly "[Method Two](Breath in Mind p. 15)".
Reviewing our meditation habits and the purpose of meditation.

With each in-breath and each out-breath, really trying to recollect that we have the opportunity to experience the Dhamma, to experience truth, to realize the fruits of the Buddha's teaching and guidance leading to liberation.

Reflecting on the second tetrad of the Ānāpānasati Sutta (MN 118), Ajahn Pasanno describes meditation as relaxing so that awareness comes to the fore and explains the importance of perception in relating to painful, pleasant, and neutral feeling.
[Breath in Mind](), particularly "[Method Two](Breath in Mind p. 15)".
Long-term effective strategies for dealing with pain.
Applying the factors of first jhāna in mindfulness of breathing.
The importance of sustaining attention with neutral sensations.
SN 36.6: The Dart.

Ajahn Pasanno elucidates the Buddha's similes for the Five Hindrances (MN 39.14). He encourages us to investigate the tone of the mind to identify the presence or absence of hindrances and to delight in the inherent well-being of the mind when the hindrances are relinquished.
Sensual desire is like being in debt. (MN 39.14)
Ill-will is like being sick. (MN 39.14)
Sloth and torpor is like being in prison. (MN 39.14)
Restlessness and worry is like being a slave.
Skeptical doubt is like a merchant travelling through a dangerous desert.
Using the breath to steep the body and mind with attention and awareness can reveal and dispel subtle hindrances. (Incomplete recording)
Bringing attention to the breath is an alternative to sensual gratification.
Recognizing subtle forms of irritation.
Tibetan Buddhism translates klesha as affliction.
Preventing the settled mind from sinking into dullness.
You have to be willing to die...and then the mind easily goes into jhāna.|Ajahn Jumnien
Following the outline of SN 46.51, Ajahn Pasanno describes the factors that feed or attenuate each of the Five Hindrances. (Incomplete recording)
Attending to attractive objects nourishes sensual desire. (SN 46.51)
Chanting Book p. 55: The Five Recollections
Attending to what we feel obstructed by nourishes ill-will. (SN 46.51)
A monk with an aversive temperament worsens it with repeated asuba and death contemplation.
Following the path of least resistance nourishes sloth and torpor. (SN 46.51)
The novice's nibbāna.
on the value of noble silence during Winter Retreat.
Ajahn Pasanno urges the Abhayagiri community to cultivate mindfulness, composure, sensitivity, and silence in the details of moving and speaking during Winter Retreat.
Abhayagiri's communal space consisted of two small buildings in 2005.
The [commentaries](Path of Purification p. 135) contast the Five Hindrances with the five factors of first jhāna.
Ajahn Boon Choo dispels sloth and torpor.
Sensual desire is like looking for the turtle with the mustache.|Ajahn Chah
Breathing with the five factors of first jhāna.
Be present with the physical experience of the breath. Bring a sense of ease into the body. Ground awareness in the body.
Keeping the breath in mind is like getting the spoon into the mouth and the mouth onto the spoon.|Ajahn Lee Dhammadharo
"The body understands!"
Body and mind are not separate things.
Water similes for the mind with and without hindrances. (SN 46.55)
DN 2.98: "These are shoals of fish..."
Composed attention to the body and reflection on Dhamma in walking meditation.
You can get a lot of wisdom from walking meditation.|Ajahn Chah
Continuing with the second tetrad of the Ānāpānasati Sutta (MN 118), Ajahn Pasanno urges us to use awareness grounded in mindfulness of breathing to investigate feelings, perceptions, and hindrances.
Winnie-the-Pooh hears a buzzing sound, associates it with honey, and begins climbing a tree.
Relaxing into the breath when experiencing pain in meditation.
Maintaining alertness in the midst of pleasant feeling.
Developing sensitivity to neutral feeling.

Beginning the third tetrad of the Ānāpānasati Sutta (MN 118), Ajahn Pasanno teaches that by attending to the mind itself with each breath, we can recognize that the direct experience of the defiled mind is suffering. Relinquishing the defilements brings peace.
MN 10.34: Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta, mindfulness of mind section.
One who is lost in the world is lost in their moods. One who is lost in their moods is lost in the world.
Three Harvard professors take a course in meditation.
"I'm not very peaceful, but I don't have any excuses anymore."
Discerning the fundamental mind base amidst the moods of the mind.
Differing interpretations of citta; returning to the knowing, our refuge of peace.

AN 10.2 explains that samādhi and liberation follow naturally from gladdening the mind with a foundation of virtue. Elucidating the tenth step of the Ānāpānasati Sutta (MN 118), Ajahn Pasanno describes various ways to allow the mind to delight in Dhamma and stillness.
Fine-tuning the balance between stillness and investigation.
SN 15.1: "Bound by ignorance and obstructed by craving."
Gladdening the mind through corpse contemplation.

Practicing the eleventh step of ānāpānasati (MN 118) involves purifying the mind of obstructive states and firmly establishing the mind with the breath so that it becomes pliant, malleable, and bright.
Delighting in the beautiful and benevolent breath.
on jhāna and attainment.
SN 43.1: "Meditate [jhāyatha] bhikkhus, do not be negligent, lest you regret it later."
Ārammaṇupanijjhāna (meditation using an object as a focus) and lakkhaṇupanijjhāna (meditation using the characteristics as a focus); when to contemplate anicca, dukkha, anatta.
The four results of samādhi described in AN 4.41.
As a novice, Ajahn Puth directed his mind to which questions would be on the Nak Tam exams.
When practicing the twelfth step of ānāpānasati (MN 118), each breath is the occasion to release the clinging that binds us to suffering.
A trap for monkeys who don't let go.
We're not diminished beings if we don't get what we want.
A dog gnawing on meatless bones (MN 54.15).
The drawbacks of wrong view and clinging to views.
Attending wisely to the breath versus blindly clinging to the practice.
MN 57: The Dog-Duty Ascetic.
Attending to what is rather than concepts about a self.
Our suffering is fed and sustained by clinging.

Introducing the fourth tetrad of the Ānāpānasati Sutta (MN 118), Ajahn Pasanno reflects on impermanence as the doorway into the relam of insight. Mindfulness of breathing can illuminate all three characteristics of impermanence, suffering, and not-self.
Making impermanence the focal point for attending to the breath.
Animitta samādhi takes impermanence as its object and is not drawn into the characteristics of things.
When one sees through dukkha, the concentration that develops is called appaṇihita samādhi.
Imagine a mental state that isn't looking for anything else.
Emptiness is the experiential counterpoint of not-self.

Passion is the deep belief in what feelings, objects of attention, and views represent. Expounding the fourteenth step of the Ānāpānasati Sutta (MN 118), Ajahn Pasanno explains how to cultivate dispassion with each in and out breath.
A man diagnosed with AIDS loses his story.
Developing dispassion by reflecting on the body.
The contemplation of death resets our priorities and lays the ground for dispassion to cool the heart of its impusles to follow desires, moods, and biases.
As dawn precedes sunrise, when one recognizes the quality of appamāda (heedfulness), one can expect the unfolding of the Eightfold Path. (SN 45.55)
Larry Rosenberg watches a 1938 film and realizes that the actors, directors, and producers are all dead.
If this were the last moment of my life, is this the kind of mental state I want to carry into death?
from Ajahn Koon Balisoodtoh: "Am I dying?" with each breath.
A group of Thai villagers are afraid to dig up their dead in order to conduct funeral rites.
A Thai monastery turns into a makeshift morgue after the 2005 tsunami.
Ajahn Chah was larger than life, but he's been dead for over 10 years now.
We will be alone when we die.
In the end, one is cooked and eaten by the King of Death.|Varapañño Bhikkhu (Paul Breiter)

Allowing things to cease is the middle way between the extremes of clinging to becoming and annihilation. Abiding in the quality of cessation between each in and out breath breaks the habit of becoming and forms the basis of peace.
The mind that does not allow cessation is like the derelict Chithurst House stuffed with junk.
The cessation of self view is a window into emptiness.
Rest attention midway between the eye and a visual object.
Samatha practices allow us to become familiar with peaceful places in our mind.
Can you be continuously angry for two hours?
Ajahn Buddhadāsa translates nirodha as quenching.

Reflecting on the last step of the Ānāpānasati Sutta (MN 118), Ajahn Pasanno explains how relinquishment is key to entering and abiding in Dhamma. He encourages us to contemplate relinquishment with each in and out breath.
Total relinquishment was a characteristic of Ajahn Chah's practice.
Practicing the Dhamma is to renounce this life.
Seeing things as they are.
Attending to the simplicity of the elements.
Ajahn Buddhadāsa translates paṭinissagga as "giving back".
Mindfulness is critical at all stages of meditation. Mindfulness of breathing develops calm, stable, focused attention and can be a vehicle for the discernment that frees us from discontent.
A Zen student complains that the breath is boring.
A moment of lack of mindfulness is a moment of derangement.|Ajahn Chah
A student gets hit by a car while engrossed in reading _Mindfulness in Plain English_.
The four constituents of Right Mindfulness.
MN 10: Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta.
Clear comprehension has the characteristic of non-confusion, its function is to investigate, and it manifests as scrutinty. (Path of Purification p. 154)
Mindfulness has the characteristic of remembering, its function is not forgetting, and it manifests as guarding. (Path of Purification p. 154)
When mindfulness is established and the breath becomes subtle, attend to the presence of the breath and the knower itself.
If you let go a little, you get a little peace. If you let go a lot, you get a lot of peace. If you let go completely, you get complete peace.|Ajahn Chah
